awd_titl_txt: EAPSI: Investigating ocean territory and resource sovereignty through seabed mining in South Pacific Island Nations
awd_abstract_narration:
EAPSI: Investigating ocean territory and resource sovereignty through seabed mining in South Pacific Island Nations



As land-based resources are diminishing, the world is looking offshore to satisfy growing appetites for food, fuel and minerals. The deep seabed is being targeted for large-scale mining, which has only recently become possible with changes in global markets and advancing technologies. However, mining rare metals and minerals from the deep seabed present a number of significant challenges to resource managers, and push the limits of scientific knowledge, technical ability and institutional capacity. This project will investigate the emerging management strategies in New Zealand and other South Pacific Island Nations as they lay the groundwork for deep seabed resource development. New Zealand is a prominent economic force in the South Pacific and has considerable influence in the region. It is also one of the first nations exploring seabed mining, which makes it a critically important site for this research. In collaboration with Dr. Nick Lewis at the University of Auckland, this project will employ a mixed methods approach utilizing archives, interviews and spatial planning data. It will examine emerging resource management strategies in New Zealand, as well as its role within the regional governance context. 

Exclusive Economic Zones (EEZ) give coastal nations a form of resource-based sovereignty up to 200 nautical miles from shore. Managing these vast ocean territories has proved challenging to institutions historically developed to govern land. Pacific Island Nations are presumed to have the most to gain from developing seabed resources because their EEZs are much larger than the resource-limited island nations. Results of this investigation will be important to developing island nations, as they struggle to advance concrete seabed management strategies with fewer economic and governmental resources. Additionally, this work will address a significant gap in critical geography scholarship on processes of territory, environmental governance and the commodification of nature in the context of marine-based resource management. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Royal Society of New Zealand.

This research investigates how New Zealand (NZ) constructs governance frameworks within its Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) in the face of economic motivations and technological advancements, which have made deep seabed mining a realistic possibility. As the impetus to mine the seabed for precious mineral resources becomes more feasible, political and practical management strategies are struggling to come to grips with the task of governing this marine space. Multiple factors drive and inhibit seabed-mining projects in NZ. Fluctuating metal markets over the last several decades have sparked interests in developing the industry, yet addressing the management of this marine environment has proven challenging. The legislation regulating such projects passed in 2012 and governance capacities are still evolving. Environmental interests, as well as competing users of marine space, have offered staunch resistance to mining proposals.

 

New Zealand’s EEZ is roughly 4 million square kilometers, almost 20 times the size of its land mass. NZ has been one of the first countries in the world to pass national legislation regulating seabed mining. However, developing these resources presents a number of significant challenges. First, assimilating such a large marine space into politically and legally organized zones strains institutional capacity to initiate and enforce regulations. Second, developing economic resources in such an extreme environment take place at the limits of scientific knowledge and technical ability in understanding seabed ecosystems and the threats posed by mining activities. As a member of several South Pacific inter-governmental organizations participating in forums on resource development, economic policy and science and technology, NZ has a large leadership role in the region. Their considerable influence in the region will determine the future of seabed mining in the Pacific.

 

The intellectual merit of this research includes improved understanding of the theoretical and practical implications of NZ’s regulation of the marine mining industry. This research reaches beyond established understandings of territory and sovereignty to examine these concepts as applied within EEZs, as they are being incorporated into national territory, and redefined socially, politically, legally and practically.  This research utilizes a unique moment in ocean development to address significant gaps in critical geography scholarship addressing territory, environmental governance and the political economy of nature; topics which have mainly been researched through land-based practices.

 

To achieve these research objectives I conducted interviews with stakeholders, scholars and scientists in Auckland and Wellington. I collected documents from NZ National Archives and government documents online government websites. This opportunity to engage in research in NZ was extremely valuable and assisted my development as international researcher. My academic host, Dr. Nick Lewis, and I worked very closely with an interdisciplinary environmental governance research group. Collaborating with this group facilitated access to an incredible network of academics and scientists. I attended the Marine Futures workshop organized by this group held at the Royal Society of NZ in Wellington. I also established a collaborative relationship with the McGuinness Institute, an environmental policy analysis non-profit. Continued collaboration with the Institute is expected to produce policy relevant papers, which will be disseminated on their website, among other venues.
